results.title: An Interview with Phil Bailey
results.brief_description: Phil Bailey was a telegrapher - one of a unique cohort of women who were trained in signalling by a forward-thinking female engineer. She has never forgotten morse code due to the wise words of her teacher.
results.description: Phil Bailey was a telegrapher - one of a unique cohort of women who were trained in signalling by a forward-thinking female engineer. She has never forgotten morse code due to the wise words of her teacher.

results.title: An Interview with Joyce Bryan
results.brief_description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.
results.description: Joyce Bryan was a witness to the return of the Prisoners of War from Japan. She provides an powerful and detailed rendering of the emotionally charged return and the struggles of the men to fit back into society.

results.title: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When he went to the cinemas, the newsreels would beckon David Higgins to ‘Join the Navy and see the world!’. And join the Navy he did, serving in the Mediterranean during World War II. He guides us through the bowels of the ship and the claustrophobic conditions therein. David also reflects on the life-shifting experience of war, how it changed his perspective on things and how little he knew at the time when he signed up.
results.title_for_label: Join the Navy and see the world
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Higgins, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: An Interview with Evelyn Warner
results.brief_description: Evelyn Warner was in London when World War II was declared. As a very young cadet, Warner cycled around the countryside delivering messages. Then one day she had an encounter with a ‘doddlebug’, an unmanned plane designed to crash and burn, that left her red-faced.

results.title: Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, Warwick talks about his early days in Alice Springs and getting his start in radio before moving on to films. Warwick also discusses the reoccurring theme of the matriarch in his works and the freedom and joy he finds in installation art.

‘Mother Courage’ is a film and sculptural installation by the internationally acclaimed artist and filmmaker Warwick Thornton. Co-commissioned by ACMI and dOCUMENTA (13) as part of the ACMI Commissions Series, ‘Warwick Thornton: Mother Courage’ was a free exhibition in Gallery Two at ACMI 2013. As one of the most exciting filmmakers working in Australia today, Warwick Thornton is best known for ‘Samson & Delilah’, winner of the 2009 Camera d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. His work, ‘Mother Courage’ (2012), is a dynamic, multi-screen art installation that features a dilapidated campervan as its centrepiece. Audiences will peer into the van’s grimy windows and through its rear doors, to view the provocative and poignant video contained within.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Arneman, Csilla Csongvay, Kim Montgomery and ACMI

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

video_links.name: Spectacle Director Showcase: Oh Yeah Wow

results.brief_description:
‘Oh Yeah Wow’ are a Melbourne based creative collective that make music videos, short films and TV programs. In this interview directors Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury and Josh Thomas discuss music videos.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Sam Mapplebeck and ACMI

results.title: One hour and twelve minutes left to live
results.creator_credit: Charlie Safstrom, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Charlie Safstrom served as a sniper in Borneo during World War II. Here he recounts one of the more frightening moments of his service where he was almost mistaken for a Japanese soldier during a late night changing of the guard.

results.title: The Traveller
results.creator_credit: John Hansen, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: John Hansen’s war experience really started after World War II. Having been seconded into the US Navy, John was there to celebrate in the streets of California when the war ended. Then he travelled the world, transporting a variety of things, from war brides to coal. In the end, the world became his classroom.

results.title: One of thousands
results.creator_credit: Ralph Basson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a veteran who served in Normandy during World War II, Ralph Basson takes us on a sensory tour of war. In this, Ralph highlights the things you cling to in order to survive. ‘With all the chaos going on around you, you have to remember your training and just put one foot in front of the other’.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ralph Basson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: [Reginald Relf]
results.creator_credit: Reginald Relf, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Reginald Relf tells of his time in the Royal Australian Air Force, training as a mechanic at RMIT in Melbourne. Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Reginald Relf, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.
description_for_label: Reginald Relf tells of his time in the Royal Australian Air Force, training as a mechanic at RMIT in Melbourne. Later he was posted in Queensland, tracking aircraft flying to and from New Guinea. As well as sharing his experiences of this time, he tells of his joy and relief when war ended.
